moe_section_title: Component release, records, occurrence reporting, storage of defective parts, electronic records, manpower planning and critical maintenance tasks
summary: Describes conditions for issuing maintenance certificates/Form 1 for components, handling and transfer of maintenance records, internal and external occurrence reporting (including EU 376/2014), handling and storage of defective parts, electronic maintenance records, manpower and resource planning, and basic control of critical/recurring error tasks.

findings.requirement_id: AMC M.A.402(g) & AMC1/2 M.A.402(h) / ML.A.402(b)(7)(8) – error‑capturing & critical tasks
findings.requirement_excerpt: To minimise the risk of multiple errors and to prevent omissions… plan different persons to perform identical tasks… when only one person is available, then this person should perform reinspection… ensure that an error‑capturing method is implemented after the performance of any critical maintenance task… CRITICAL MAINTENANCE TASKS…
findings.reasoning: The MOE defines a ‘critical task’ as repeated work by the same person on one or many systems and states that creation of such tasks is prevented by planning and task allocation, or by an additional check when only one person is available. However, it does not: (1) define critical maintenance tasks in line with the examples in the AMC (flight controls, stability systems, propulsion, etc.); (2) describe a systematic process and data sources for identifying critical tasks; (3) clearly define the independent inspection/reinspection concept, roles (‘authorised person’ vs ‘independent qualified person’), documentation of the reinspection on work cards, or the conditions under which reinspection is allowed when only one person is available; and (4) does not explicitly require an error‑capturing method after any critical maintenance task as such, only for the specific ‘recurring error’ scenario it defines.
findings.recommended_fix:
Expand and clarify the ‘CRITICAL MAINTENANCE TASKS CONTROL’ subsection as follows:

1) Definition and identification of critical maintenance tasks
- Add text such as:
  "Critical maintenance tasks are those whose incorrect performance could have a significant effect on flight safety. As a minimum, the following tasks are considered for classification as critical:
   • tasks that may affect the control of the aircraft, flight path and attitude, such as installation, rigging and adjustment of flight controls;
   • tasks that may affect aircraft stability control systems (e.g. autopilot, fuel transfer systems);
   • tasks that may affect the propulsive force of the aircraft, including installation of engines, propellers and rotors;
   • overhaul, calibration or rigging of engines, propellers, transmissions and gearboxes; and
   • any other tasks identified from accident/incident reports, occurrence reporting, audits, flight data analysis, feedback from training or information from the design approval holder.
  The Technical Director is responsible for ensuring that critical tasks are identified, listed and kept up to date in the maintenance planning and work card system."

2) Error‑capturing method and independent inspection
- Add a dedicated subsection, for example:
  "For each critical maintenance task, an error‑capturing method shall be applied after completion of the task. The primary method used by the organisation is independent inspection:
   • The ‘authorised person’ is the person who performs or supervises the task and is responsible for its completion in accordance with the maintenance data.
   • The ‘independent qualified person’ is a person, other than the authorised person, who performs an independent inspection of the completed task and confirms that it has been correctly carried out and that no deficiencies have been found. The independent qualified person does not issue the certificate of release to service and is not required to hold certification privileges.
   The independent inspection shall be recorded on the work card or electronic task record, including the identification of the authorised person, the independent qualified person, the date and a reference to the inspected task."

3) Reinspection when only one person is available
- Add text aligned with the AMC concept of reinspection, for example:
  "If, in unforeseen circumstances, only one person is available to perform a critical maintenance task, reinspection may be used as an error‑capturing method. In this case, the authorised person performs the task and then performs a reinspection of the task after a suitable break. The circumstances are considered unforeseen only when the grounding of the aircraft or the need for the task could not reasonably have been predicted and no suitable independent qualified person can be made available. The work card shall record that reinspection has been used, including the date, details of the reinspection and the identification of the authorised person. The certificate of release to service is issued only after satisfactory reinspection."

4) Multiple‑error prevention in identical tasks
- Clarify the existing text to state explicitly:
  "To minimise the possibility of an error being repeated in identical tasks involving removal/installation or assembly/disassembly of several components of the same type fitted to more than one system, maintenance planning shall, whenever practicable, assign different persons to perform identical tasks on different systems. Where this is not possible, the error‑capturing method described above (independent inspection or reinspection) shall be applied."

findings.requirement_excerpt: The maintenance man-hour plan should relate to the anticipated maintenance work load… reviewed at least every 3 months and updated when necessary… significant deviation (>25 % shortfall) should be reported… organisation should have a procedure to assess and mitigate the risks if the actual number of staff available is less than the planned staffing level…
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes that the Technical Director prepares an annual maintenance and resource plan based on anticipated orders, includes a +25 % margin based on manufacturer and empirical data, considers support tasks, updates plans up to 3 months in advance, and addresses overload via work transfer, overtime or temporary workers. Overload cases are discussed in quality meetings. However, it does not: (1) explicitly state that the man‑hour plan is reviewed at least every 3 months; (2) define ‘significant deviation’ as >25 % shortfall in available man‑hours in a calendar month and require reporting to the compliance monitoring manager and accountable manager; (3) explicitly include all maintenance workload elements listed in the AMC (planning, records checks, worksheets, inspections, etc.); and (4) describe a formal risk assessment and mitigation procedure when actual staff is below planned levels, including the link to the management system/compliance monitoring function.
findings.recommended_fix:
Amend the ‘LABOR RESOURCES AND MAINTENANCE PLAN COMPARISON’ subsection as follows:

1) Review frequency and content of the man‑hour plan
- Add:
  "The maintenance man‑hour plan covers all maintenance activities, including planning, maintenance record checks, preparation of work cards/worksheets (paper or electronic), accomplishment of maintenance, inspections and completion of maintenance records, as well as support activities (administration, training, customer service). The plan is formally reviewed at least every 3 months and updated when necessary."

2) Significant deviation and reporting
- Add a definition and reporting line:
  "A significant deviation from the maintenance man‑hour plan is defined as more than a 25 % shortfall in available man‑hours during a calendar month for any of the functions covered by 145.A.30(d). Any significant deviation shall be reported by the Technical Director through the relevant departmental manager to the Compliance Monitoring Manager and the Accountable Manager for review. Such deviations may also be reported through the internal safety reporting scheme."

3) Risk assessment when staffing is below plan
- Add a risk‑based procedure:
  "If the actual number of staff available on any shift or period is less than the planned staffing level, the Technical Director (or delegate) shall perform and document a risk assessment. This assessment will consider the type and volume of work, criticality of tasks, available competence, and potential impact on safety and compliance. Based on the assessment, appropriate mitigation measures (e.g. rescheduling work, limiting scope of maintenance, using additional contracted staff, increased supervision or independent inspections) shall be implemented. The assessment and mitigations shall be recorded and made available to the Compliance Monitoring Manager."

4) Link to compliance monitoring
- Add:
  "The Compliance Monitoring Manager monitors the effectiveness of the man‑hour planning process and the handling of significant deviations as part of the management system in accordance with 145.A.200."

findings.requirement_id: AMC1 145.A.30(d)(1) – proportion of employed vs contracted staff
findings.requirement_excerpt: at least half the staff that perform maintenance in each workshop, hangar or flight line on any shift should be employed to ensure organisational stability… temporary increase of the proportion of contracted staff may be permitted… in accordance with an approved procedure…
findings.reasoning: The MOE section on labour resources and maintenance planning does not address the required balance between employed and contracted maintenance staff, nor does it describe any procedure for temporarily increasing the proportion of contracted staff with competent authority approval.
findings.recommended_fix:
Add a paragraph to the labour resources section, for example:
  "In each workshop, hangar and flight line, on every shift, at least 50 % of the staff performing maintenance shall be directly employed by the organisation to ensure organisational stability. The remaining proportion may be contracted staff. If, due to specific operational necessity, it is required to temporarily increase the proportion of contracted staff above this level, this will only be done in accordance with a procedure approved by the competent authority. This procedure will define the extent, specific duties and responsibilities of contracted staff and the measures to ensure adequate organisational stability and oversight."

findings.requirement_id: AMC1 145.A.30(d)(2)(3)(5)(6)(7)(8) – scope, review and reporting of man‑hour plan
findings.requirement_excerpt: The maintenance man-hour plan should take into account all maintenance activities… relate to the anticipated maintenance work load… reviewed at least every 3 months… significant deviation… reported through the departmental manager to the compliance monitoring manager and the accountable manager…
findings.reasoning: The MOE covers anticipated workload, includes support tasks, and mentions updating plans up to 3 months in advance and recording implementation. However, it does not explicitly state the 3‑monthly review requirement, the reporting chain for significant deviations, or the link to the compliance monitoring function as described in the AMC.
findings.recommended_fix:
Complement the existing text with explicit statements:
- "The maintenance man‑hour plan is reviewed at least every 3 months and updated when necessary, taking into account all maintenance activities, including those outside the scope of the Part‑145 approval where they affect resource availability."
- "Significant deviations (more than 25 % shortfall in available man‑hours in a calendar month for any function) are reported by the Technical Director via the relevant departmental manager to the Compliance Monitoring Manager and the Accountable Manager for review and corrective action."

findings.requirement_id: AMC1 ML.A.402 & AMC1 ML.A.402(b)(7) – recording and sign‑off of maintenance
findings.requirement_excerpt: ensure that all maintenance performed is properly recorded and documented… every maintenance task is signed off only after completion; the grouping of tasks for the purpose of sign-off allows critical steps to be clearly identified; any work performed by personnel under supervision… is checked and signed off by an authorised person.
findings.reasoning: The MOE states that maintenance records are stored in secure databases with backups and that maintenance certificates and documents are provided to the operator, with copies retained. However, it does not explicitly state that every maintenance task is signed off only after completion, that task grouping allows critical steps to be clearly identified, or that supervised work (temporary staff, trainees) is checked and signed off by an authorised person. The description of electronic records focuses on storage and access control, not on the content and sign‑off principles.
findings.recommended_fix:
Enhance the maintenance recording and electronic records sections with:
- "Every maintenance task is signed off only after its completion. The work cards or electronic task records are structured so that critical steps are clearly identified and can be individually checked and signed off where necessary."
- "Any work performed by personnel under supervision (e.g. temporary staff, trainees) shall be checked and signed off by an authorised person holding the appropriate certification privileges. The records shall clearly show who performed the work and who performed the supervisory sign‑off."
- "The electronic maintenance record system shall capture, for each task, at least: task reference, maintenance data reference, date, person performing the task, person performing any independent inspection (if applicable), and the certifying staff issuing the certificate of release to service."

findings.requirement_id: AMC2 M.A.402(h) – documentation of independent inspection/reinspection
findings.requirement_excerpt: The work card system should record the identification of the ‘authorised person’ and the date and the details of the reinspection, as necessary, before the certificate of release to service is issued.
findings.reasoning: The MOE mentions that if different persons cannot be used, the task will be subject to an additional check when all repeated work stages have been completed, but it does not define how this additional check is documented in the work card system, nor does it require recording the identification of the person performing the reinspection and the details of the reinspection before issuing the CRS.
findings.recommended_fix:
Add explicit documentation requirements to the ‘CRITICAL MAINTENANCE TASKS CONTROL’ section:
- "When an independent inspection or reinspection is used as an error‑capturing method, the work card or electronic task record shall include:
   • identification of the authorised person who performed/supervised the task;
   • identification of the independent qualified person (or, in case of reinspection, the authorised person performing the reinspection);
   • date and time of the inspection/reinspection; and
   • a brief description or reference to the scope of the inspection/reinspection.
  These entries shall be completed before the certificate of release to service is issued."

findings.requirement_id: General performance of maintenance – minimising multiple errors (AMC M.A.402(g), ML.A.402(b)(7))
findings.requirement_excerpt: To minimise the possibility of an error being repeated in identical tasks… plan different persons to perform identical tasks in different systems. However, when only one person is available, then this person should perform reinspection of the tasks…
findings.reasoning: The MOE recognises the risk of repeated errors by the same person and states that creation of such critical tasks is prevented through planning and appropriate task allocation, and that if this is not possible an additional check is applied. However, it does not clearly state that different persons should be planned for identical tasks on different systems, nor does it describe the reinspection concept and conditions in sufficient detail (e.g. unforeseen circumstances, how reinspection is performed and recorded).
findings.recommended_fix:
Clarify the existing text as follows:
- "For identical tasks involving removal/installation or assembly/disassembly of several components of the same type fitted to more than one system, maintenance planning shall, whenever practicable, assign different persons to perform the tasks on different systems to minimise the risk of repeated errors. If only one person is available, that person shall perform a documented reinspection of the tasks after completion, in accordance with the reinspection procedure described in this section, before the certificate of release to service is issued."

findings.requirement_id: Performance of maintenance – general verification and tool/part control (ML.A.402(b)(9))
findings.requirement_excerpt: perform a general verification after completion of maintenance to ensure that the aircraft or component is clear of all tools, equipment and any extraneous parts and material, and that all access panels removed have been refitted;
findings.reasoning: The provided MOE text does not clearly describe a general verification step after maintenance to ensure that tools, equipment and foreign objects are removed and that all access panels are refitted. Such a step may be described elsewhere in the MOE, but it is not evident in this section.
findings.recommended_fix:
If not covered elsewhere, add a short, explicit statement in the maintenance recording or critical task section, for example:
- "After completion of maintenance, a general verification shall be performed to ensure that the aircraft or component is free of tools, equipment and foreign objects, and that all access panels, cowlings and fairings removed for the work have been correctly refitted and secured. This verification shall be recorded on the work card or electronic task record."

findings.requirement_id: Component release and EASA Form 1 – conditions for issuing release certificate
findings.requirement_excerpt: In working order detached assemblies and equipment… issues a Part-145 release certificate… for a device or equipment if… [conditions related to last use, preservation, inspection, accident history, defect reports, maintenance status].
findings.reasoning: Although not directly tied to a specific excerpt, the MOE describes detailed conditions under which a Part‑145 release certificate (EASA Form 1) may be issued for serviceable parts removed from an aircraft or subassembly, including limits on time since last use, preservation in accordance with TCH instructions, absence of corrosion/leakage/damage, confirmation that the part has not been involved in an accident/incident/lightning strike, absence of related defects in transferred fault lists, and traceability of maintenance and modification status. It also specifies the information to be recorded on the maintenance certificate and documents. This is consistent with typical Part‑145 expectations for used component release.

findings.requirement_id: Occurrence reporting – internal and to authority/TC holder (EU 376/2014 context)
findings.requirement_excerpt: All defects and maintenance observations that hinder airworthiness and endanger flight safety are reported, analysed and evaluated… serious defects or malfunctions… shall be reported to the NAA, the State of Registry and the TC holder… within 72 hours… deviations described in Annexes I and II of EU Regulation 376/2014… voluntary reporting of safety observations…
findings.reasoning: The MOE sets out an internal reporting system for defects and maintenance observations affecting airworthiness, including analysis of risks, causes and consequences, and integration into safety and quality activities. It states that any person can report, that management ensures a non‑punitive environment, and that personnel are informed of observations and actions. It requires reporting serious defects or malfunctions to the NAA, State of Registry and TC holder within 72 hours, referencing EU 376/2014 Annexes I and II, and also commits to voluntary reporting under EU 376/2014. It describes feedback to reporters and provision of copies of reports to the operator/CAMO. This aligns well with the occurrence reporting expectations reflected in the provided excerpts.

findings.requirement_id: Storage and control of defective parts
findings.requirement_excerpt: Removed from aircraft for defective some are made usage classification… attached accompanying card… follows it until repaired or scrapped… defective parts are returned to external contractors with an appropriate accompanying card… parts that cannot be repaired are mutilated…
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes classification of defective parts, use of accompanying cards indicating use classification, control of parts until repair or scrapping, and mutilation of unrepairable parts, as well as returning defective parts to external contractors with appropriate documentation. This is consistent with typical Part‑145 expectations for segregation and control of unserviceable components, even though no specific excerpt on this topic was provided.

findings.requirement_id: Electronic maintenance records – protection and access control
findings.requirement_excerpt: Maintenance records are stored in secure databases… continuously backed up… deleted files can be restored for 90 days… access… managed by user rights granted by the quality manager… protected from damage, theft and counterfeiting.
findings.reasoning: The MOE specifies that electronic maintenance records are stored in secure cloud databases, backed up continuously, with a 90‑day restore capability. Access is controlled via user rights managed by the quality manager, who also ensures protection against damage, theft and counterfeiting. This meets the general expectations for integrity, security and controlled access to maintenance records, even though no specific Part‑145 excerpt on electronic records was provided.
